text.0: While it doesn’t have the region’s highest death rate, #Nigeria had the highest number of estimated deaths from cancer in Africa in 2018 because of its large population. https://t.co/fxobCw0GAI
text.1:
How many #Nigerian women die from cervical cancer daily? The most recent data shows 10,403 die from the disease every year. This translates to at least 28 deaths every day. 

We therefore rate this claim as mostly correct. https://t.co/fxobCw0GAI
text.2:
:medical_symbol_selector: A cancer advocate has claimed that every day in #Nigeria 26 people die of cervical #cancer - a preventable disease - and that the country has the highest death rate from cancer in #Africa.

Is this accurate? https://t.co/fxobCw0GAI
text.3: But no data supports the claim of 40% of Nigerians suffering from mental health challenges, a mental health expert said. https://t.co/dLBm5d6zzt
text.4: 1 in 8 Nigerians have had a mental illness in their lifetime, @AfricaCheck found in a previous #factcheck. The most common were depression & anxiety disorders. https://t.co/idvAPHwV6r
text.5:
We checked a similar claim in 2019 & found there were 250 registered psychiatrists & 200 psychiatry trainees under the Association of Psychiatrists in #Nigeria. 

This number hasn’t changed. https://t.co/idvAPHOwv1
text.6:
:Nigeria: Does #Nigeria have only 350 psychiatrists for a population of about 200 million? 

And do up to 40% of the population suffer from mental health challenges? https://t.co/dLBm5d6zzt
text.7: @flysaa But as the then deputy director of B-BBEE procurement, transformation & verification at @the_dti told Africa Check in 2017, it is “wrong to say 98% went to white-owned companies”. A proportion would have gone to state-owned enterprises. https://t.co/OkpbChzWxC
text.8: @flysaa .@flysaa’s latest financial report does not reveal what percentage of local spending was spent on ‘100% black’ or ‘white companies’. The airline declined to say. https://t.co/OkpbChzWxC
text.9: @flysaa .@flysaa failed to file financial reports in 2017/18 & 2018/19. The latest financial report, for 2016/17, revealed that 95% of local spending went to B-BBEE compliant companies. https://t.co/OkpbChzWxC
text.10:
@flysaa But it was wrong to say the remainder went to “white-owned companies”. 

27.5% went to state-owned enterprises, which are measured against a specialised B-BBEE scorecard that *excludes* the assessment of racial ownership. https://t.co/OkpbChzWxC https://t.co/T3qaecmYIV
text.11:
@flysaa A 2017 #factcheck of a similar claim by @MbalulaFikile determined that 95% of the airline’s local spending went to B-BBEE compliant companies. 

But just 1.7% went to companies considered “100% black”. https://t.co/OoTDiaQqwa
text.12: @flysaa .@flysaa’s local spend has to meet the requirements of #SouthAfrica’s Broad-Based Black Economic Empowerment (B-BBEE) Act & codes. A number of targets have been set to increase the participation of black people in the ownership & management structures of enterprises.
text.13: :airplane_selector: No, 98% of #SouthAfrica’s national airline @flysaa’s spending doesn't go to ‘white companies’ as claimed by a Twitter user who named former chairperson Dudu #Myeni as the claim’s source. https://t.co/OkpbChRxWc
